message.content: Geranium carolinianum, also known as Carolina crane's-bill, is a herbaceous plant that belongs to the family Geraniaceae. It typically grows up to 30 cm tall and spreads up to 60 cm wide in a basal rosette. The leaves are green and palmately lobed with five to seven pointed segments that are 2-5 cm long. The flowers are usually bright pink-purple with five petals and bloom from April to June. The plant prefers to grow in moist, well-drained soils and is commonly found in open fields, meadows, and along roadsides. The fruit of Geranium carolinianum consists of a long, narrow, five-parted capsule that splits into dispersing units when mature. Overall, the plant has a delicate and intricate appearance, with its colorful blossoms, finely textured foliage, and upright stems.
